<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 123, 637, 146]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 185]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 165, 237]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 213, 424, 259]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[724, 220, 720, 237]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[867, 220, 872, 237]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[39, 256, 80, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 230, 292]]<|/det|> MATHEMATICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 304, 341, 319]]<|/det|> Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[762, 305, 908, 321]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 328, 907, 343]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 395, 372]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 386, 391, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: List of formulae (MF19) <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 225, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 291, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 761, 467]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 481, 565, 497]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 867, 545]]<|/det|> - If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 482, 575]]<|/det|> - You should use a calculator where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 881, 591]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 854, 620]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 669, 214, 680]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 683, 388, 698]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 50. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 715]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
1 It is known that \(1 \%\) of houses in a certain area have a wind turbine. A random sample of 400 houses in this area is chosen for a survey on domestic heating. The number of houses in the sample that have a

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 350, 122]]<|/det|>
wind turbine is denoted by \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 581, 153]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximating distribution to find \(\mathrm{P}(X \leqslant 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 918, 105]]<|/det|>
2 The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{B}\left(8, \frac{3}{4}\right)\). A random sample of 100 values of \(X\) is chosen, and the sample mean, \(\bar{X}\), is found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 700, 148]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\mathrm{P}(\bar{X}>6.2)\). You are not expected to use a continuity correction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 765, 769, 783]]<|/det|>
(b) State why the Central Limit Theorem was needed in the calculation in part (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
3 The time, \(T\) minutes, for a certain daily bus journey is normally distributed. The bus company claims that the mean of \(T\) is 45 . A passenger believes that the mean of \(T\) is actually greater than 45 . She notes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 888, 122]]<|/det|>
the times taken for this journey on a random sample of 60 days. The results are summarised below.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 134, 686, 153]]<|/det|>
\[
n=60 \quad \sum t=2750 \quad \sum t^{2}=127000
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 675, 183]]<|/det|>
(a) Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 474, 590, 495]]<|/det|>
(b) Test the passenger's belief at the \(5 \%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
4 At an entertainment centre, the cost for using a particular video game is \(\$ 0.40\) per minute. The number of minutes for which people use the video game has mean 15 and variance 9 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 777, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the mean and variance of the amount people pay for using the video game.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 521, 551, 540]]<|/det|>
Each day, 35 people independently use the video game.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 552, 672, 571]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the mean and variance of the total amount paid by 35 people.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
5 (a) The random variables \(W\) and \(X\) have the independent distributions \(\operatorname{Po}(1.2)\) and \(\operatorname{Po}(2.3)\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 105, 385, 122]]<|/det|>
(i) Find \(\mathrm{P}(3 \leqslant W+X \leqslant 5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 320, 918, 339]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(S\) is the sum of 100 independent values of \(W\) and 200 independent values of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[152, 351, 584, 369]]<|/det|>
(ii) Use a suitable approximation to find \(\mathrm{P}(S>600)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 661, 93]]<|/det|>
(b) The random variable \(Y\) has the distribution \(\operatorname{Po}(\lambda)\), where \(\lambda>0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 97, 551, 128]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{P}(Y=3)+\mathrm{P}(Y=4)=\mathrm{P}(Y=5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 136, 314, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
6 A manufacturer of cell phones claims that \(25 \%\) of students own a Pumpkin phone. Jeyeraj thinks that the proportion of students at his large college who own a Pumpkin phone is less than \(25 \%\). He plans to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
test the manufacturer's claim. He chooses a random sample of 30 students at his college. If the number of students who own a Pumpkin phone is less than 5 , Jeyeraj will reject the manufacturer's claim.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 150, 446, 167]]<|/det|>
(a) State suitable hypotheses for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 336, 918, 353]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that the true proportion of students at the college who own a Pumpkin phone is \(10 \%\), use a binomial distribution to find the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 898, 91]]<|/det|>
At Florence's college, in a random sample of 40 students, it was found that 5 own a Pumpkin phone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
(c) Calculate an approximate \(95 \%\) confidence interval for the proportion of students at Florence's college who own a Pumpkin phone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 628, 91]]<|/det|>
\(7 X\) is a random variable with probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[350, 107, 648, 146]]<|/det|>
\[
\mathrm{f}(x)= \begin{cases}(1+\cos \pi x) & 0 \leqslant x \leqslant 1 \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 160, 396, 191]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that \(\mathrm{P}\left(X<\frac{1}{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{\pi}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 74, 567, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
